description:
Human alphaherpesvirus 2, also known as Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2), is a DNA virus that belongs to the Herpesviridae family, specifically the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily. It is one of the causative agents of genital herpes, a sexually transmitted infection (STI) that primarily affects the genital and anal regions.

HSV-2 is a double-stranded DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid surrounded by a lipid envelope. The virus is capable of establishing latent infections in the sensory neurons of the infected individual, where it can remain dormant for extended periods before reactivating and causing recurrent outbreaks.

The virus primarily spreads through direct contact with infectious lesions or body fluids, such as during sexual activity. Once inside the host, HSV-2 can infect and replicate in various cell types, including epithelial cells and nerve cells. The virus can then travel along the sensory nerves and establish latency in the dorsal root ganglia, where it can remain dormant for years or even decades.

Reactivation of the virus can be triggered by various factors, such as stress, illness, or immunosuppression, leading to the development of genital herpes lesions or other clinical manifestations. HSV-2 infections can also increase the risk of acquiring and transmitting other sexually transmitted infections, such as HIV.

Effective antiviral medications are available to manage the symptoms and reduce the frequency of outbreaks, but the virus cannot be completely eliminated from the host. Ongoing research aims to develop improved treatment strategies and potentially a vaccine to prevent HSV-2 infections.
